bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Wildlife Act;

antlerless animal means a member of the deer family bearing no visible bony antlers and, for the purposes of this definition, the small skin or hair covered protuberances on male fawns and calves are not antlers;
bait means any thing, including meat, cereal, cultivated crops, a restrained animal or any manufactured product or material, that may attract wildlife, but does not include a decoy;
bearded turkey means a turkey with a tuft of hair-like feathers that grow larger with age, and are found on the chest of the turkey;

brow palm, in relation to an antler of a moose, means the lateral branch that is separated from a main palm by the deepest antler bay, and for the purposes of this definition the deepest antler bay is the antler bay whose vertex is the shortest distance from the antler base when measured along the surface of the antler;
brow tine means the first lateral branch, of an antler of deer, elk, moose or caribou, that projects forward and occurs in the lower one third of the antler;
buck or bull with reference to deer, moose or elk means one bearing visible bony antlers, but does not include a calf;
buck or bull with reference to caribou means a male bearing visible bony antlers, but does not include a calf;
calf in reference to a moose, elk or caribou means one that is less than 12 months of age;
compound crossbow means a crossbow on which the bow string passes through a series of pulleys;
cougar kitten means a spotted cougar, or a cougar less than one year of age, as determined by the regional manager or designate;
decoy means a material or manufactured product that simulates the appearance or has the form of wildlife;
feral pig has the same meaning as in section 3.2 (1) of the Designation and Exemption Regulation, B.C. Reg. 168/90;
full curl bighorn ram mountain sheep means any male bighorn mountain sheep,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the head of which, when viewed squarely from the side, has at least one horn tip extending upwards beyond a straight line drawn through the centre of the nostril and the lowest hindmost portion of the horn base, or

the skull and horns of which are presented for examination, and which, when viewed squarely from the side with both horns in alignment, have at least one horn tip extending upwards beyond a straight line drawn through the lowest hindmost portion of the horn base and the lowermost edge of the eye socket;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: full curl thinhorn ram mountain sheep means any thinhorn ram mountain sheep that has attained the age of 8 years as evidenced by true horn annuli as determined by the regional manager or designate, or whose horn tip, when viewed squarely from the side at right angles to the sagittal plane of the skull, extends dorsally beyond the nose bridge plane;

horizontal plane means the surface intersecting the ventral posteriormost portion of the base of the left and right horns, the ventral portion of the most complete eye-socket retained with the skull and that is at right angles to the sagittal plane;
infrared optics means an optical device with the capacity to detect infrared radiation;
kid means a mountain goat with horns that are less than 100 mm in length;

lateral plane means the surface intersecting the ventral anteriormost portion of the most complete eye-socket retained with the skull and that is at right angles to the sagittal and horizontal planes;
licence year means the period April 1 to March 31 next following;
management unit or M.U. means an area designated as a management unit by B.C. Reg. 64/96, the Management Unit Regulation;

mature bighorn ram mountain sheep means any bighorn ram mountain sheep whose horn tip, when viewed squarely from the side at right angles to the sagittal plane of the skull, extends dorsally beyond the nose bridge plane;
migratory game bird means a migratory game bird as defined in the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994 (Canada);
non-toxic shot means shotgun pellets consisting of, by weight, not more than one percent lead;

nose bridge plane means a plane perpendicular to the sagittal plane that includes the anterior and posterior points of the suture joining the left and right nasal bones where they meet the dorsal surface of those bones;
plane means a surface such that the straight line that joins any 2 of its points lies wholly in that surface;

possession limit means the maximum number of a species or type of wildlife which a person may have in the person's possession while hunting or returning from hunting, except for migratory game birds where the possession limit applies at all times;

power boat means a boat, canoe or yacht powered by electric, gasoline, oil, steam or other mechanical means, but does not include a boat powered manually nor a boat with an outboard motor provided the motor is tilted or otherwise disengaged so as not to be ready for immediate use;
sagittal plane means the surface by which the skull is divided equally into left and right sides;
spike buck means a male deer having antlers that are composed of a main beam from which there are no bony projections greater than 2.54 cm (1 inch) in length;
spike bull means a bull elk having antlers that are composed of a main beam from which there are no bony projections greater than 2.5 cm in length;
three quarter curl bighorn ram mountain sheep means any male bighorn mountain sheep,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the head of which, when viewed squarely from the side, has at least one horn tip extending beyond a straight line drawn through the back of the eye opening and at right angles to a line drawn between the centre of the nostril and the lowest hindmost portion of the horn base, or

the skull and horns of which are presented for examination, and which, when viewed squarely from the side with both horns in alignment, has at least one horn tip extending beyond a straight line drawn through the back edge of the eye socket and at right angles to a line drawn through the lowest hindmost portion of the horn base and the lowermost edge of the eye socket;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: tine or point means the branch of an antler which is longer than its breadth and is at least 2.5 cm (1 inch) in length, and for the purpose of determining the length of a tine

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the breadth of the tine is measured (if extending from a palmation of an antler, then in the plane of the palm) at a location at least 2.5 cm (1 inch) from the tip of the tine, and

the length of the tine is measured from its tip end, following the midline of the profile of the tine, and following the natural curvature of the tine, to the midpoint of the straight line along which the breadth is measured;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: vehicle means a wheeled or tracked device in, on or by which a person or thing is or may be transported or drawn on a highway;
wireless camera means a camera that obtains an image by means of a remote or infrared sensor and that is capable of sending an image remotely to an electronic device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 195/99, s. 2.]

Unless specifically stated, this regulation does not apply to fur bearing animals taken by trapping during an open season for trapping, by a person who holds, or is exempted from holding, a trapping licence.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 166/2001, s. 3.]
A map referred to in this regulation is in Schedule 9 unless the area shown on the map is referred to as described in the Limited Entry Hunting Regulation.
In this regulation, unless another period of time is specified, a bag limit in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mammals or turkeys is for one licence year, and
any other birds is for one day.

bcl:section.bcl:text: All dates and all references to descriptions by means of serial numbers in this regulation are inclusive, unless otherwise indicated.
For the purpose of this regulation, the Province of British Columbia is divided into the following regions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Region 1 — Vancouver Island, comprised of Management Units 1-1 to 1-15 (including a part of the mainland coast in the vicinity of Knight and Seymour Inlets);
Region 2 — Lower Mainland, comprised of Management Units 2-1 to 2-19;
Region 3 — Thompson-Nicola, comprised of Management Units 3-12 to 3-20 and 3-26 to 3-46;
Region 4 — Kootenay, comprised of Management Units 4-1 to 4-9 and 4-14 to 4-40;
Region 5 — Cariboo, comprised of Management Units 5-1 to 5-16;
Region 6 — Skeena, comprised of Management Units 6-1 to 6-30 including Haida Gwaii;
Region 7 — Omineca-Peace, comprised of Management Units 7-l to 7-58;
Region 8 — Okanagan, comprised of Management Units 8-1 to 8-15 and 8-21 to 8-26.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The open seasons for the hunting of each species and type of game animal, subject to section 6, are those set forth in Parts 1 and 2 of each Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When open seasons not in effect
bcl:section.bcl:text: An open season declared by this regulation shall cease to be in effect in any area

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: while the area is subject to a closure order issued by the Forest Service of the Ministry of Forests and Range, or
if hunting is prohibited by an order of the minister under section 40 of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Where an open season is marked in Part 1 of a Schedule by a double asterisk, the restrictions set out in Part 2 of that Schedule apply.
A person who hunts, takes or kills game and fails to comply with a restriction under subsection (1) commits an offence.
A person who lawfully possesses raptors under a permit for the purpose of falconry may use a raptor to hunt small game during a bow only season as set out in Part 2 of each Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Where a bag limit is marked in Part 1 of a Schedule by a triple asterisk, the restrictions set out in Part 3 of that Schedule apply.
The abbreviation NBL in Part 1 of each Schedule means "no bag limit".

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Examples of bag and possession limits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An entry such as "2 (1)" in Part 1 of a Schedule means, in the case of ungulates, that the bag limit is 2 animals of that species in the aggregate, one of which may be antlerless.
An entry such as "10 (20)" in Part 1 of a Schedule means, in the case of all game birds except turkeys, that the bag limit is 10 birds a day, while the possession limit is 20.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to section 11 (2), a person commits an offence where the person exceeds the bag limit or possession limit for an area as set out in Part 1 or Part 3 of each Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Offence — species or type of animal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to exceptions for areas noted in Parts 1 and 3 of each Schedule, a person commits an offence where the person exceeds the Provincial bag limit for a species or type of animal as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 3 deer, of which only one may be a mule deer buck from Region 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 or 8;
one mountain sheep of the genus Ovis;
one big game animal of a species other than those referred to in paragraphs (a) to (e);

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Where a bag limit in an area is higher than the Provincial bag limit for a species or type of animal, a person commits an offence where the person kills more than the number of animals permitted by the higher bag limit less the number of animals of that species or type taken by the person anywhere else in the Province.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to the exceptions noted in Parts 1 and 3 of each Schedule, a person commits an offence where the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 10 geese in one day,
8 ducks in one day,
4 canvasback ducks in one day,
4 pintail ducks in one day,
2 goldeneye ducks in one day,
2 harlequin ducks in one day,
5 band-tailed pigeons in one day,
10 coots in one day, or
10 common snipe in one day, or
30 geese,
24 ducks,
12 canvasback ducks,
12 pintail ducks,
6 goldeneye ducks,
6 harlequin ducks,
3 times the daily bag limit for game birds, excluding migratory game birds,
15 band-tailed pigeons,
30 coots, or
30 common snipe.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person commits an offence where the person takes or kills any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a grizzly bear less than 2 years old or a grizzly bear in the company of it;
a black bear less than 2 years old or a black bear in the company of it;
a white or blue (glacier) coloured black bear;
a cougar kitten or a cougar in the company of it;
a female mountain goat in the company of a kid or in a group that contains one or more kids;
a lynx in the company of one or more lynx;
a bobcat in the company of one or more bobcats.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An offence under subsection (1) of this section is prescribed as an offence for the purposes of section 84 (1) (b) (ii) of the Act.
The prohibited hours for hunting wildlife are from one hour after sunset on any day until one hour before sunrise of the day following.
Despite subsection (1), the prohibited hours for hunting migratory game birds are from one-half hour after sunset on any day until one-half hour before sunrise of the day following.
In subsection (2.1), deer means mule (black-tailed) deer, white-tailed deer and fallow deer.

For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the whole carcass or part of a carcass of an elk or moose must leave naturally attached to the carcass, or one part of the carcass in the person's possession, the animal's tail or another readily identifiable part of the hide not less than 6 cm2 and,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the animal was male, a testicle or part of the penis, or
if the animal was female, a part of the udder or teats.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the whole carcass or part of a carcass of a deer must leave naturally attached to the carcass, or one part of the carcass in the person's possession, the animal's unskinned tail and,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the animal was male, a testicle or part of the penis, or
if the animal was female, a part of the udder or teats.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the whole carcass or part of a carcass of a caribou must leave naturally attached to the carcass, or one part of the carcass in the person's possession, the animal's tail or another readily identifiable part of the hide not less than 6 cm2 and,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the animal was male, a testicle or part of the penis, or
if the animal was female, a part of the udder or teats.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the whole carcass or part of a carcass of a mountain sheep must leave naturally attached to the carcass, or one part of the carcass in the person's possession,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the animal was male, a testicle or part of the penis, or
if the animal was female, a part of the udder or teats.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the whole carcass or part of a carcass of a mountain goat or bison must leave naturally attached to the carcass, or one part of the carcass in the person's possession,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the animal was male, a testicle or part of the penis, or
if the animal was female, a part of the udder or teats.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the carcass of a game bird other than a migratory game bird must leave one wing and its plumage naturally attached to the carcass.
For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the carcass of a migratory game bird must leave one wing and its plumage, or the head and its plumage, attached to the carcass.
Despite subsections (2) to (6), a person who possesses a part of a carcass or hide does not commit an offence under section 36 (1) of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person did not kill the wildlife in the person's possession,

the person who killed the wildlife possesses a part of the carcass or hide with the parts attached as required by subsection (2), (2.1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) until, under section 36 (2) of the Act, section 36 (1) of the Act no longer applies to that person,
the person possesses the part of the carcass or hide for the purpose of transporting it to a person or destination referred to in section 36 (2) of the Act, and
the person is transporting the part of the carcass or hide in compliance with section 37 of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to the carcass of the following wildlife:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a mountain goat or mountain sheep;

a caribou, deer, elk or moose if, during the season in which the caribou, deer, elk or moose is taken or killed, hunting of the wildlife is restricted based on the number of tines or points on the antlers of that wildlife.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 36 of the Act, a person who possesses the carcass of wildlife to which this section applies must leave the antlers or horns, as applicable, naturally attached to the upper portion of the skull of the carcass.
An antler or horn that has been altered or tampered with in any way after the animal is taken or killed is not naturally attached for the purpose of subsection (2).
A person commits an offence if the person takes or kills,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any M.U. except in Region 4 (Kootenay) or in Region 6 (Skeena), a cougar,
in Region 4 or 8, M.U. 5-3 to 5-6, 5-10 to 5-14, 6-1 to 6-11, 6-15, 6-17 to 6-30 or that portion of M.U. 7-52 outlined in red on map '2022 M.U. 7-52 Moose Compulsory Inspection', a moose,
in Region 3, during a season described in Schedule 3, a moose,
in Region 4, 5 or 8, a bobcat, or
in M.U. 6-12 or 6-13, a black bear,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: unless the person submits the prescribed parts of the animal to an officer for inspection and measurement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 30 days after the date the animal was taken or killed, and
if applicable, before exporting the animal from the Province.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 158/2020, Sch. 2, s. 2.]
A person commits an offence if the person takes or kills, in any M.U.,
unless the person submits the prescribed parts of the animal to an officer for inspection and measurement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 30 days after the date on which the animal was taken or killed,
if applicable, before exporting the animal from the Province, and
before December 5 of the year in which the animal was taken or killed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person does not commit an offence under subsection (1) (k) or (2.1) (d) or (f) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the written approval of an officer, the prescribed parts of a big game animal are submitted for inspection within 30 days after the last day of the hunt, or
all of the following conditions are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the animal taken or killed was
the person took or killed the animal using the services of a guide outfitter;
the prescribed parts of the animal are submitted to an officer for inspection and measurement within 30 days after the last day of the open season in which the animal was taken or killed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsections (2.1) and (2.2), inspection and measurement of a mountain sheep must include the insertion into the horns, by an officer, of a numbered aluminum plug.

A person commits an offence if the person takes or kills a cougar in Region 4 or Region 6 unless the person submits the prescribed parts of the cougar to an officer, for inspection and measurement, in the region where the cougar was taken or killed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 4 days after the date the cougar was taken or killed, and
if applicable, before exporting the cougar from the Province.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 158/2020, Sch. 2, s. 6.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 168/2007, s. 1 (a).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 157/2022, App. 5, s. 2 (d).]
For subsections (1), (2.1), (2.2), and (3) the parts to be submitted are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an incisor (front) tooth, and
in the case of males, the antlers naturally attached to a portion of the upper skull, or
in the case of females, the upper portion of the skull or a portion of the teats or mammary gland,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a grizzly bear, a black bear, a lynx, a bobcat or a cougar, the skull and the hide that bears

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of males, either a testicle or a part of the penis, or
in the case of females, a portion of the teats or mammary gland,
the portion of the skull that includes, naturally attached to the skull, the nasal bones, eye socket, horns and the associated connective bone structure, and
an incisor tooth, if the mountain sheep is a Dall's or Stone's mountain sheep,
the horns, and
in the case of males, either a testicle or a part of the penis, or
in the case of females, a portion of the teats or mammary gland,
a front incisor tooth,
the antlers, and
for a caribou without at least one main beam measuring over 60 centimetres (24 inches) in length, the hide with evidence of sex naturally attached, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a moose, an incisor tooth, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of males, the antlers naturally attached to a portion of the skull, or
in the case of females, the upper portion of the skull or a portion of the teats or mammary gland.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person takes or kills an animal referred to in subsection (1), (2.1) or (3), the person commits an offence unless the person reports the taking or killing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within the applicable submission period set out in subsection (1), (2.1) or (3), and

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 112/2023, App. 1, s. 1 (b).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 175/2010, App. 2, s. 4 (b).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 216/2000, s. 9.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 77/2010, App. 1, s. 1 (b).]
A person who takes or kills

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any M.U., a feral pig, or
in M.U.s 7-19 to 7-22, 7-31 to 7-36, 7-42 to 7-51, in that portion of M.U. 7-52 outlined in red on map '2022 M.U. 7-52 Moose Compulsory Reporting' and in M.U.s 7-53 to 7-58, a moose,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: commits an offence if the person fails, within 30 days after the date on which the animal was taken or killed, to report the taking or killing in accordance with section 16.3.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 222/2005, s. 3 (b).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 168/2007, s. 2 (d).]
Despite sections 16 and 16.1, if a person who holds an initiation hunting licence or on whose behalf a youth hunting licence is held takes or kills an animal referred to in section 16 or 16.1,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sections 16 and 16.1 apply to the supervising hunter as though the animal was taken or killed by the supervising hunter, and
the person who takes or kills the animal is exempt from sections 16 and 16.1.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section supervising hunter and youth hunting licence have the same meaning as in the Hunting Licensing Regulation.
In this section:
animal class means the animal class listed in Schedule 10 that applies to an animal that was taken or killed;
report means a report that must be made under section 16 (5) or 16.1 (1) with respect to an animal that was taken or killed.
A report must be made in the manner and form specified by the director.
Subject to subsection (4), a report must include all of the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the animal class of the animal that was taken or killed;
the location and date of the taking or killing of the animal;
the number of days hunted before the animal was taken or killed;
the type of weapon used to take or kill the animal;
all licence numbers under which the taking or killing of the animal was authorized;
whether or not the taking or killing of the animal was authorized under a limited entry hunting authorization;
in the case of a report made under section 16 (5), the name, address and telephone number of the person who took or killed the animal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) (e) of this section does not apply to a person to whom section 11 (1) (a) and (c) and (8) of the Act does not apply.
A person commits an offence where the person hunts

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a full metal jacketed non-expanding bullet, or
a tracer, incendiary, or explosive bullet,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: big game, other than lynx, bobcat or wolverine, with a rifle using a rimfire cartridge,
with a shotgun using a tracer or incendiary shot shell,
caribou, elk, grizzly bear, moose, mountain sheep or mountain goat with a weapon other than a bow, muzzleloader or rifle,
deer, black bear, cougar, coyote, lynx, bobcat, wolverine or wolf with a shotgun

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: smaller than 20 gauge, or
using a shot shell loaded with shot smaller than the shot size 1 Buck,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: game birds, other than turkey, grouse and ptarmigan, with a rifle,

small game, game birds, other than migratory game birds, lynx, bobcat, wolverine, mule (black-tailed) deer, white-tailed deer or fallow deer with a crossbow, other than a compound crossbow, having a draw weight of less than 55 kg,
big game, other than deer, lynx, bobcat or wolverine, with a crossbow, other than a compound crossbow,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: having a draw weight of less than 68 kg, or
having a bolt with a broadhead less than 2.22 cm at the widest point,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with a compound crossbow having a draw weight of less than 45 kg,
with a crossbow having a bolt weighing less than 16.2 g,
with a bow having a draw weight of less than 18 kg,
big game with a bow using an arrow with a broadhead less than 2.2 cm at the widest point,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by placing bait, or
by using a dead animal or part of it as bait,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: migratory game birds by using a power boat, unless the boat is beached, resting at anchor or fastened within or tied immediately alongside of a fixed hunting blind,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a weapon other than a shotgun or a bow,
a shotgun loaded with a single projectile,
a shotgun larger than 10 gauge,
more than one shotgun unless each shotgun in excess of one is

bcl:clause.bcl:text: disassembled or kept in a closed case,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a longbow

bcl:clause.bcl:text: having a draw weight of less than 18 kg, or
using an arrow with a broadhead less than 22 mm at its widest point or less than 2 sharp blades, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a crossbow

bcl:clause.bcl:text: having a draw weight of less than 45 kg, or
using a bolt with a broadhead less than 22 mm at its widest point or less than 2 sharp blades,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: waterfowl, coot or snipe while using shot other than non-toxic shot,
turkey with a rifle using a centrefire cartridge,
bison with a weapon other than

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a centrefire rifle and ammunition other than ammunition constructed with a 175 grain or larger bullet which retains 2 712 joules (2 000 foot pounds) or more energy at 100 metres, or
a bow having a draw weight greater than 22.6 kg, an arrow greater than 26 grams in weight and a broadhead greater than 8.1 grams in weight and 2.2 cm in width at its widest point,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with a firearm that is designed, altered or intended to be aimed and fired by the action of one hand or that has a barrel less than 305 mm in length,
with a firearm that has an electronically controlled firing mechanism,
big game, other than bison, caribou, elk, grizzly bear, moose, mountain sheep or mountain goat, with a weapon other than a bow, muzzleloader, rifle or shotgun,
black bear, bobcat, cougar, deer, goat, lynx, sheep, wolf or wolverine with an air rifle that is less than .35 calibre, or
big game, other than an animal referred to in paragraph (v), with an air rifle.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An offence under subsection (1) (m) of this section is prescribed as an offence for the purposes of section 84 (1) (b) (ii) of the Act.
A person who possesses shot, other than non-toxic shot, for the purpose of hunting waterfowl, coot or snipe, commits an offence.
A person who hunts big game with a shotgun loaded with single-projectile ammunition is exempt from section 26 (1) (h) of the Act.
In this section, drone means an aerial vehicle that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not occupied or operated by a person within the vehicle,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: remote control,
pre-programmed software,
onboard computer autonomy or artificial intelligence, or
any combination of subparagraphs (i) to (iii), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is capable of attracting, searching for, chasing, pursuing, following after or on the trail of, stalking, spotting or monitoring wildlife.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person commits an offence if, while on a hunting or trapping expedition, the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has a drone in that person's possession, charge or control, or
uses information that a drone obtains during, or less than 6 hours before the start of, the expedition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An offence referred to in subsection (2) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 84 (1) (b) (ii) of the Act.
A person commits an offence where the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: retrieves a dead or injured game animal by the use of a power boat while that person is in possession of a loaded firearm,
while hunting, discharges a firearm from a vehicle to which a draught animal is attached,
hunts migratory game birds within 400 m of any place where bait has been deposited unless that place has been free of bait for a minimum period of 7 days,
continues to hunt a species of wildlife

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on the day on which the person has taken that person's daily bag limit, or
on or subsequent to the day on which the person has taken that person's seasonal bag limit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: uses a vehicle to which a draught animal is attached to disturb game for the purposes of driving the game towards another hunter,
uses live birds as decoys or recorded bird calls to hunt game birds,
carries a cocked crossbow in or on a vehicle,
hunts with a bow or discharges a bow from a vehicle of any kind,

uses recorded or electronic calls for the purpose of hunting wildlife, other than for hunting wolf, coyote, cougar, lynx, bobcat or any bird listed in Schedule C of the Designation and Exemption Regulation, B.C. Reg. 168/90,
hunts game, other than small game or wildlife listed in Schedule C of the Designation and Exemption Regulation, B.C. Reg. 168/90, with a raptor,
hunts while accompanied by, or with the use or aid of, a goat or sheep, including by using the goat or sheep as a pack animal,
hunts in any M.U. in Region 6 or 7, except in M.U. 6-12 or 6-13, while accompanied by, or with the use or aid of a camelid, including by using the camelid as a pack animal,
uses, for the purpose of hunting wildlife, any part or derivative of a deer, elk, moose or caribou if the part or derivative originated from outside British Columbia,
while on a hunting expedition, uses or possesses infrared optics,
hunts using information on the location of wildlife that is obtained by means of an aircraft,
shares, or assists in sharing, information on the location of wildlife that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: obtained by means of an aircraft, and
shared for the purpose of hunting wildlife, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: uses a wireless camera for the purposes of hunting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in Region 1, at any time of the year, and
in Regions 2 to 8, from August 1 to December 10.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person does not commit an offence under section 78 of the Act where the person, while hunting, causes or allows a dog to pursue

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: small game, black bear, bobcat, lynx or cougar, or
mule (black-tailed) deer, white-tailed deer, fallow deer, sheep, goat, caribou, elk or moose if the dog is on a leash and under the direct control of the person,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: provided the game is being pursued in an area in which and at a time at which an open season exists for that game and also provided the person holds a valid hunting licence and is otherwise conforming with the requirements of the Act and regulations.

A person does not commit an offence under section 78 of the Act where the person causes or allows a dog to pursue game birds between the dates August 1 to April 30 provided the dog is under supervision of the person.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 115/2018, App. 2, s. 5 (c).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 225/92, s. 4 (b).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 203/94, s. 4.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 169/2020, App. 3, s. 8.]
Between June 16 and September 9, inclusive, of each year, for the purpose of section 26 (1) (c) of the Act, there is no open season in the following parks and recreation areas:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: E.C. Manning Park — that portion in M.U. 2-17 only

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Between April 16 and September 19, inclusive, in each year, for the purpose of section 26 (1) (c) of the Act, there is no open season in the following parks:
Between July 1 and August 31, inclusive, in each year, for the purpose of section 26 (1) (c) of the Act, there is no open season in the following parks and protected areas:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Gladstone Park, that portion in M.U. 8-15 only

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Between July 1 and August 31, inclusive, in each year, for the purpose of section 26 (1) (c) of the Act, there is no open season in the following parks, conservancies and protected areas:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Gladstone Park, that portion in M.U. 4-14 only
Tweedsmuir Park — that portion in M.U.s 5-10 and 5-11

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except during the open season, for the purpose of section 26 (1) (c) of the Act, a person must not hunt in the following parks, conservancies, recreation areas and protected areas:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Protected Area (M.U. 5-7)
Anhluut'ukwsim Laxmihl Angwinga'asanskwhl Nisg̱a'a (a.k.a. Nisg̱a'a Memorial Lava Bed Park) (M.U.s 6-14, 6-15)
Bishop Bay — Monkey Beach Corridor Conservancy (M.U. 6-3)
Bowron Lake Park — those portions in M.U.s 5-15, 7-5 and 7-6
Brim River Hot Springs Protected Area (M.U. 6-3)
Cape Scott Park including the drainage areas of the Nahwitti Shushartie (M.U. 1-13)
Dahl Lake Park — Henry and Chuk Lakes addition only (M.U. 7-12)
Eskers Park — Taginchil Lake addition only (M.U. 7-15)
Gwillim Lake Park — that portion which does not drain into Gwillam Lake only (M.U.s 7-21, 7-22)
Jáji7em and Kw'ulh Marine Park [a.k.a. Sandy Island Marine Park] (M.U. 1-6)
Lac du Bois Grasslands Protected Area (M.U.s 3-28, 3-29)
Lax Kwaxl/Dundas and Melville Islands Conservancy (M.U. 6-10)
Monkman Park — that portion in M.U. 7-18 only
Mount Robson Park — Swift Current Creek addition only (M.U. 7-13)
Nakina — Inklin Rivers (Kuthai Area)/Yáwu Yaa Conservancy (M.U.s 6-25, 6-26)
Purcell Wilderness Conservancy Corridor Protected Area (M.U. 4-26)
Strathcona Park — McBride Creek addition only (M.U. 1-7)
Strathcona Park — Megin Creek addition only (M.U. 1-8)
Takla Lake Marine Park — Takla West Site (M.U. 7-27)
Takla Lake Marine Park — White Bluff Site (M.U. 7-27)
Tweedsmuir Park — that portion in M.U. 6-1, 6-2

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 157/2022, App. 5, s. 7 (a).]
For the purpose of section 26 (1) (c) of the Act, there is no open season

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: between April 1 and September 14 in Naikoon Park (M.U. 6-13),
between June 1 and September 19 in Wells Gray Park (M.U.s 3-40, 3-46),
between April 16 and August 24 in Cathedral Park (M.U. 8-3),
between December 1 and October 31 in Kokanee Glacier Park (M.U.s 4-17, 4-18), and
between April 1 and September 30 in Tā Ch'Ilā Park [a.k.a. Boya Lake Park] (M.U. 6-23).
